They play catchy music that almost everyone knows and that is easy to dance to. This is great, but the 4 times that I've been there they literally place the SAME EXACT songs. What's more, every time we try to talk to the DJ (it's been the same guy every time we go) he says they don't take requests. My boyfriend tried to get him to play a popular salsa song so our large group of friends could dance to it and he said "sorry we don't play that type of music here"... he then played a Pit Bull song and said that's the closest to salsa he can do -.- Overall I love the place it's just somewhere I wouldn't go that frequently because they never change up the music.

Worst Food in the Southwest?

This is a very unique  place. I'm sure there are good reasons to go there, but please, don't go there for the food. And if you do go there, make sure you eat first. Go to drink, dance, party ... but not to eat.  Horrible food, egregiously overpriced.

We went for lunch.  We were the only people there at noon,  not a good sign.  The ribs were simply terrible. For $14, you got  ... six small ribs; that is all.  They were clearly warmed over, and appeared to have been cooked day or two or a week? earlier. And they were barely warm. Simply dreadful.  One of us ordered the sliders, and they were equally ghastly.

Great atmosphere.  Great food!  Great company!

We first saw this place on DDD and though it looked interesting. We then found it in the Best of Phoenix and were intrigued. 

Their dips were great for starters. The meals and desserts we had were good as well. The atmosphere was awesome. While you are waiting for your meal you can enjoy the live DJ, play ping pong or corn hole. They offer karaoke and boxing on specific nights as well.

Had a great time!

Not worth the cost. I have absolutely no problem paying more if I get more, quality not quantity wise. The Duce didn't deliver. I spent over $20 for 3 sliders, a bag of chips, small lemonade, and a slice of banana cream pie. Plus I had to walk up to order and pick up my meal myself. 

The pie ($5) was good, but not good enough to salvage my meal. The bag of chips ($4) were burned and salty. The sliders ($8 for 3, no sides) were alright at best but served a little cold. My lemonade ($3 for a small mason jar) was way too sweet.   

I really wanted to like this place. It has tons of potential. The decor is cute. The building is great. But the layout is difficult to navigate and doesn't really maximize all the services being offered. Multi-purposed spaces are not a new concept! The execution is just off. So is the cooking.

The Duce is one of my favorite spots in downtown Phoenix. Unfortunately, the drinks are somewhat overpriced in my opinion, and they still don't have A/C. So the drinks are just ok, I've yet to try any of their food, and the service in my experience has always been very average.

Now that I've got all that out of the way, The Duce is still a cool place to hang out. It's a truly unique atmosphere. They've got plenty of games (including ping-pong tables and cornhole!), they've got hula hoops, they've got punching bags, and even a boxing ring (although this is out-of-bounds for the general public most of the time).

The on-site retail store is trendy though (again) high-priced. It's fun to look at, but I would never shop there. If nothing else, it does add to the general ambiance of the establishment.

NOTE: be sure to check their calendar for a list of weekly events. They've been doing a lot of really fun events lately, not the least of which is the every-Tuesday South Central Swing Night which consistently draws a large and interesting crowd of regulars.

Made it to the Duce for an after party after a wedding on Saturday night. 

The bar did a great setup for the group allowing us to have exclusive access to the bar just inside the building to the left. 

While I can not talk to prices (open bar) the drinks were great.  How can you go wrong with a muddled drinks made from fresh ingredients. Our two favorites were strawberry limeade and a basil mule.

I go here to swing dance Tuesday nights with my boyfriend which is always a blast. I am never able to make swing classes because I get off work. This seems to be the only venue that serves alcohol which helps me get over my swing dancing jitters (I am much more attuned to salsa, belly dance and hip hop). I like the hoola hoops and games in the other room so that friends who don't dance can still be entertained. They may want to move one of the tables out of the way to make the dance floor a bit larger. 

I have eaten here once. Rachel was super helpful. She was bussing above and beyond and accidentally took my sliders before I was done, which are delicious. When I asked her about it, she ordered me a whole new batch. The bartenders are half descent. The older lady is cute but a bit slow and the other one looks like a bar back and isn't aggressive at all. He didn't say hi to us at the bar so I waited for the older lady and he ended up serving someone who came to the bar after me. I bartended for years and would never let something that happen. I will definitely come back though as this place is super fun.

We pulled into the so-called parking lot which is very narrow and full of potholes (in Phoenix? ), so we pulled out and parked on the street.  We went in through the store, the place is cavernous. We were directed to the food truck.  Saw pEople working out in the boxing ring.  It was chilly,  headed to a table with a heater to wait for the food.  There is table tennis,  cornhole, and foosball to play while you wait.  The food was very good,  We tried the pecan French toast,  mac and cheese muffins,  homemade chips with onion dip,  strawberry bruschetta and pb and jam sliders.  They were out of jam,  so they used honey and bananas. The hot chocolate was made from scratch,  so it took a half hour to make.  Other than a few glitches,  it was a fun place to go with tasty food.  Next Time,  I would try at night to see the vibe and have drinks at their antique bar.

This place deserves a great review for it's concept and uniqueness. Don't come here if you are expecting the norm.  This multi purpose building (boxing gym, bar, clothing shop, bike shop, bar, pie shop, restaurant) can be a one stop shop for just about anyone.  I have not had the pies but the food and drink menu is definitely up to par with the great detail that has been put here.  Don't let the area freak you out, yes its a bit dead and maybe not the best place to ride your cruiser too but definitely worth a shot.

DRESS FOR THE WEATHER! Luckily for us, someone gave us the heads-up that there is no AC, so we showed up in appropriate desert attire. So, if you don't mind the glimmer of sweat on your forehead then this is the bar for you! I think this place is pretty Avant-garde in comparison to the typical phoenix bar scene. You do feel transported to Minnesota circa 1960 on a hot summer day. The indoor decor looks like it's been purposely chosen from a garbage dump but that's the point! The rusty old designs combined with a bit of pinterest-inspired barn chic decor really give this place it's personality. So, don't be a hater and just go with the flow. The drinks are pricey but at least you get what you're paying for! The salty mad dog is so delightful and refreshing, especially after you've worked up a sweat playing ping pong, foosball, or hula-hooped 'til you dropped. Maybe that's the point...more sweat = more money spent on drinks! And if you're a fan of the Cubs there is a whole section of the gift shop dedicated to Cubs paraphernalia. Lots of other goofy shirts for sale as well, if you're into that! Also, they have a large projector screen hanging down in front of some bleachers; the first time I went they were playing an old movie, and then the second time they were playing a sports game. I would love to come back again when the temperature comes down a bit, I'm sure this would be a very fun spot to hang out on a Fri/Sat night.

Used to love this place...cool environment.  But, the staff of amber crombie frat boys are beyond terrible. Never have I ever been treated so poorly downtown than I have here. Worst moment: valet guys tried to pick a fight with me and flicked me off as I was leaving...I did nothing to provoke. Advice: get staff with customer service skills not a bunch of pompous frat boys.

Truly a unique space! The food was 3-4 stars but the drinks are 5 stars hands down. The bartenders for the event we were at were true artists! I love all the fresh fruits and unique ingredients that go into their signature drinks. Great selections as well. I have been twice now and both times had appetizers and they were all good but not great. The chicken sausage was not good at all however. The meatball sliders were the best and the brisket was pretty good. Services was attentive and fast considering how many of us there were. They have all kinds of fun games to enjoy, boxing rings for certain nights, some kind of salsa or other dancing lessons on the night we were there, etc. Unique place to have some fun when you are downtown or want to have an event or just a few drinks. They do valet the cars, no charge just tips :) Always a bonus when trying to find parking downtown!

My party and I happened to find The Duce while waiting for our conference to start. We were smitten when we walked in to the open eating area. The hostess greeted us and explained how to order food and to look around at the fun retro stuff. Where else can you find corn hole, ping pong, and boxing in one place?? The food was amazing! We ordered the family slider sampler and picked short ribs and brisket. They were both so delicious and very filling. We also enjoyed the Mac n cheese muffins-heaven!!! I just wish we had saved room for dessert!! I guess I will have to wait until my next visit.

I visited the Duce during the Urban Wine Walk  April 20.

When we arrived there was an A-Frame sign up notifying patrons about the Happy Hour Specials.  It was the beginning of Happy Hour and we were excited to save a few bucks on some cocktails.  We waited at the bar and there was no rhyme or reason to how the bartenders were taking orders from guests.  We waited, and waited, and waited, and literally had to flag down someone to allow us to pay top dollar for drinks.  There were no mac and cheese muffins as advertised on the Urban Wine Walk website and map.  

https://maps.google.com/maps/ms?msid=212580392842748430696.0004cd4c1e46626d4526f&msa=0

When we were told our total we asked about it being Happy Hour.  The female bartender said there was no Happy Hour even though there was a sign.  So, we paid our $4 extra to avoid a scene.  Interestingly enough, the A-Frame sign with the specials was gone.  I believe some people were being charged happy hour and others were not.  We were not provided any receipt for our cash purchase.  I called The Duce at 4:54, during their supposed Happy Hour, and asked about Happy Hour.  The bartender, Brandon, said they did have Happy Hour.  I asked where the A-Frame sign went and he said he didn't know.  I gave him my name and number to give to the owners because I wanted to discuss the situation with the owner.  I did not receive a call as of 5/17 so I emailed the address listed on the Duce's website. 

Within an hour of my email, I spoke to the owner and instead of saying, "Gee thanks for notifying me to this" he ripped me a new one and said he does charity work and has been open for three years and he was asked to support the event.  He never acknowledged my concerns. 

Update:  The owner called me back to tell me off about this post.  

You can listen to the voicemail here:  http://youtu.be/is34g74NZw0

I'm sorry sir, but I can afford to drink at your place or anywhere else I choose to spend my money.  I do have a job, and it pays quite well.  Rest assured, I will never be returning to the Duce.  Aptly named, Duce, as in a fecal movement.

On the Ale Walk I try here in Phoenix. Off the beaten path. Super cute inside! Something fora all age groups to look at! That's at best to say! Ordered the Mac & cheese biscuits as shown on Triple D. Super disappointed!! 25 mins later cold cold cold!!!  Hate to take back but we all walked to sample (not nice area). Booo!!! I sent back got back luke warm sample but worse condition. Crowd was much more pleasant than staff  and food nothing great.  Head closer to stadium action. This place isn't ready for prime time!!

So had heard about The Duce many times prior but never believed the hype. Went over there last Saturday night after a couple of other stops throughout the day and the DJ was rockin' it from the moment I stepped foot in the establishment until they shut it down!!!  Great atmosphere, kind of on a younger tip as it relates to the clientele and the staff but great energy and a lot of fun! We ordered food, they were really down to barebone minimums by this time so we ordered a combination of the sliders: meatball sliders, which were my fave-brisket sliders, and chicken sausage sliders. Each of them were good but in my opinion the meatball were the best! Definitely recommend this spot if you're out to have a good time and dance the night away. Also, there are other activities on site which are really cool as well. So go have fun and enjoy!

The Duce!

This is a pretty cool place. Very unorthodox bar. It is a bar that doubles as a retail store, a boxing gym, and a middle school basketball court. Not really, but it may confuse you the first time you walk in. 

But seriously, this place has a boxing ring, a set of bleachers, and a bunch of shirts and clothes that I still do not know if they are for sale. It's a large warehouse building that is split into many sections all with different themes. They have a game section, with bags, foosball, ping pong and hula hoops. There's a dance floor behind the boxing ring, and a large open patio area with a dessert station. 

I haven't yet been hungry at the Duce, so I haven't tried the food, but from what I hear, it's pretty solid. They call your name on the PA once it's ready. Thought that was cool. They also have alcoholic shakes if that gets you going. 

I cannot see how one can be bored at all here. There is too much to do, which in the Duce's case is not a bad thing. The best way I can really sum up the Duce is by calling it a clusterf*ck of cool sh*t. Call an Uber and pop in (there is like no parking...but it's a bar and you shouldn't be driving anyway.)
Terrible food!!! good ambience but food is horrible. Great music and it was a fun place with good service. everyone is friendly they just need to upgrade the food.

Loved it!

Sliders were awesome! Very unique concept that works!

Go for date nite, drinks, or bring the kids!
Best part of the Duce is  the Karaoke host Luis! Was there last night and the crowd went wild when Luis did what he does best, host Karaoke. Great night, good crowd, good times.
This was a very neat place. Restaurant, shop, games, etc. I tried to the chicken pot pie in a jar that was featured DDD. Lovely people and awesome food. The atmosphere was so, so cool.

I am new to Phoenix and have heard about this place so we stopped there for lunch today. It was 110 degrees outside and I would never think any place with no a/c would be open. The place had fans, but it was just blowing hot air throughout the tin roof building. I read through these reviews and am surprised the air conditioning was only mentioned once. We were literally sweating the whole time and couldn't enjoy the atmosphere or food because of the heat. Granted we were the only two there eating lunch so locals probably know to not eat here when it is hot outside. But why the heck would you be open and put your employees through the torture?!

Some good ideas...zero execution. Literally the biggest shit show I've ever experienced. Food was quoted as an hour wait. We were here for a bday party so accepted it. Waited over an hour and a half. I would recommend coming on a week day if you have to subject yourself to it at all

I have to be honest...if you're going for the Mac n cheese muffins, then go. Those were the ONLY positive experience myself and 3 friends had at The Duce. Maybe it was an off day for the restaurant, but I felt there were too many issues to give it a good rating. The atmosphere and decor is pretty cool though!

1. There were two weddings going on. We accidentally walked through one to the "Sweet Shop" after the hostess/bartender told us we could order dessert there. We were talked to by another employee who was upset we did this. We tried to explain that we were told the opposite. When we went to order dessert from the food truck, we were told we'd have to wait 20 minutes.
2. They were out of so many things. Could've been the fact it was Sunday night and a holiday weekend, so it was understandable. They had none of the pie jars, which was upsetting.
3. There were multiple over-served customers (not part of the weddings) that were seemingly not asked to leave. They were stumbling around and displaying way too much PDA for a family-oriented place.
4. We were told we'd be brought our food because they were not using the microphone due to the wedding. About 20 minutes later, we hear our name called for pick up. This was confusing.
5. Almost none of the baskets at tables had any forks and all of the water stations were empty. We had to ask for plain water for my friend with a fruit allergy and were met with unfriendly help.
6. When we finally ordered two milkshakes and asked for to-go cups, we waited another 15 minutes only to get them delivered in jars. Cue another 5 minute wait for the transfer.

Overall, the food was decent but the lack of communication amongst employees was extremely discouraging. We wanted to like it.

Fun place for sure. But very un organized. Ordered ribs and they lost the order. My girl ordered banana bread somethin and it was suppose to have ice cream. ... no ice cream. Not to mention they didn't even give her utensils. Hopefully I'll get my ribs soon.

Years ago, we met up with some friends for a going away party at The Duce, and my husband and I were thoroughly impressed. It was one of the first times we experienced craft cocktails that require a fair amount of labor to create rather than the standard stuff we used to drink in college. The food was good, and the atmosphere was fun. We started recommending The Duce to people based on that one visit.

Since it had been so long (5+ years) from our first visit, we decided to hit up The Duce after a Suns game. The atmosphere was still great especially with the beautiful weather, and it wasn't too crowded. In fact, the bar was missing its bartender. We waited for awhile and was told by another employee that he would return, but we started giving up hope. He finally returned while I placed our food order.

I experience the same delay at the food trailer. A couple people told me the cashier would return. After some time, the cooks finally paged the girl overhead. No apologies for the delay, just like with the bartender. The food did come out quickly, but it was wrong. We ordered plain chips, but the kitchen was out. Of course, the cashier failed to inform me. They told me I could get a refund which normally I wouldn't do for $4, but considering the minuscule portion size (just a bit more than a handful), I waited yet again to get my money back.

The drinks were much worse than what we experienced on our first visit. My husband's old fashioned was more of a cooler because it had soda in it. My brown derby was drab and overly sour.

Next time we're downtown, we'll head over to the Palomar where we can get much better food and drinks for the same price.

This place looks awesome. What they have done to this dusty building is amazing. I love the vintage look and the decorations. The bad... $4.50 for a PBR? At happy hour? Are you kidding? I'm no beer snob but I like an ipa or even a pale ale. Nowhere to be found. They only had these old Milwaukee beers. I mean that's cool if you're going with the theme but have more beer maybe? A pint of Santan epicenter was $6.50. No thanks. I'm outta here.

I am in love with this space. It is amazingly awesome. Um, why isn't there a place like this in SF??? Seriously, you would think that SF would be cool enough to have a place like this, but I sure as heck haven't found out about it in the last 6 years. 

Anyways, enough venting. The Duce is super rad. Why? You just need to see it. My mom took us here, because she was meaning to check it out herself. It's basically a large warehouse space that has everything vintage/modern. There are tables outside to eat at, as well as a food truck. Inside there are more tables, and a tasty lookin' selection of grub. There are little counters around the edge of the rest of the space, for milkshakes, etc. Ahhh it would be sooo much fun to go to an event here at night, or just a cool place to hang out. I also liked the items they had for sale, ESP the adorable pink polka dot girly aprons. I really should've bought one, what was I thinking?? 

Basically it's awesome. Period.

Dinner and dancing, both are top notch. The pie crust is perfect, I had the chicken potpie.  Trust me, anything will taste great in that little pie crust lined mason jar.   My wife had the sliders wrapped in lettuce, between the grilled onions and seasoned beef there is a ton of flavor in those little guys.  

On Tuesdays they East Cost Swing and Charleston.  When we were there the crowed was a great mix of 40-60 people of all types and skill levels.  It was a super cool sweaty celebration with more smiling and laughing then a comedy club.  

Until you are inside this place is sketchy; the downtown location, parking and the building itself give off a vibe after dark somewhere between urban decay and warehouse district.  The payoff is inside and well worth the adventure.  See you there!

It was an interesting experience coming to Duce. I couldn't tell what the place was. Bar part restaurant part boxing gym part clothing store.  It would have been nice to have gotten an explanation as to what Influenced the design. 

The service was some of the worst I have ever seen. The woman who took our order was very rude and unhelpful.  Several times everyone in our party saw her giving us evil looks from behind the bar. Very awkward. 

On the bright side the food was great. The rib and brisket sliders were delicious. Another let down was that there were no free refills. That would have been fine if the drinks weren't served in kid sized glasses. 

To conclude, the poor service cost Duce a good review and a repeat customer. There. Good food is not enough to get me to go back. Instead next time I'm on that side of town looking for bite to eat I will go to Lo-Lo's chicken and waffles across the street.
If you like hipsters, hippies,and over priced shit food with bartenders who cant even make a Greyhound or White Russian then this is the place for you.
So fun, but it is pricey! Boxing ring, ping pong, corn hole...plenty to keep you busy all night!

Some friends and I were in Phoenix from So Cal visiting. My buddy who lives there said we should check this place out, super cool vibe; music, atmosphere, drinks and the staff were all spot on! I travel a lot and have never ran into a place quite like this. Great service from all the staff there, especially two really cute girls who worked at one of the bars by the door( Briana and Maddy) if you decide to stop by, Deff look out for them! I'll for sure stop by next time I'm in town!

Let me start by saying the space is fantastic. Steve and Andi Rosenstein have put the time into this place to make it great. The attention to detail doesn't go unnoticed.

I've been coming to this building for a few years now, both for events and to occasionally check out the couple's retail concept, R&R Surplus, which has occupied the heart of the building for a while now. When they trucked in the bar from an old Capone Chicago haunt about a year ago, I knew something special was brewing. 

I love the patio space, with ample hangout room, close proximity to the bar area and easy view of your food cooking on the open grill or in the airstream trailer kitchen. The flat-screen TV has become a go-to spot for Suns games, which I'm totally cool with.

Inside, it can be a bit of a sensory overload -- let's see... there's a bar, a coffee bar, a soda fountain, a produce stand, the R&R Surplus area, a flower shop, a milk stand (yes), a gym, bleacher seating and rehabbed old school Schwinns littered about. There's even foliage in there, so it's hard to concentrate on one thing. I respect what they're doing, but I can't imagine many people will be walking up to the coffee area's streetside window. We'll see.

I'm not crazy about the parking situation. I'm not sure if it's out of necessity, but it seems the place at least shares a couple of adjacent lots, and the fences and blockades around the parking areas make it a bitch to get in and out (seriously). I've been here a couple of times now, and when it's packed, you can wait a long time to get your car back, even if it's parked within eyesight. 

Yes, the cocktails are a bit pricey. But, I've been impressed with each I've tried so far (Moscow Mule, screwdriver and a punchy spiked lemonade). The $3 beers ain't bad, either.

They seriously need to do something about paying at all the different sections. I don't know if they need a computer system or what, but opening a tab at the bar, then closing it, then paying for food at the kitchen, then paying for food at the grill, then going back to the bar (and that's just food and drink!) is absurd. I offered this suggestion to an employee and pretty much blew it off. Not what I was hoping for.

Yes, there are some kinks, but the potential of the concept is hard to ignore. This could really be a shining jewel of the Warehouse District. And no, it's not really off the beaten path, people. It's three blocks from US Airways Center.

Imagine every hipster, Pinterest-inspired wedding you've ever seen. Then mix all that into an overblown cliche. The Duce would be the result.

Mason jars everywhere. Park benches as tables. Barnyard and rustic "chic." And they ask for your "crazy nickname" when you order. I was waiting to find the photo booth.

Overhyped if you ask me. I can see why Guy Fieri would recommend it.

Mega overpriced menu with very limited options. The kitchen is an airstream trailer.

Also, it's half gym...? Weird.

Many mixed signals at this place. This could be a duffer or a must-go depending on what you want:

2 stars - process. You have to go up to one window to order your food. You have to go to a different place to get your drinks. You spend more time away from your table than hanging out with your friends. The bar drinks are delish but they take forever and you are standing at the bar the whole time waiting for them to be painstakingly crafted.

5 stars - vibe. Super chill, laid back, a little hipster. Certainly come-as-you-are. Chill picnic tables, both high and low tops with hangout-type yard games. Loved it.

2 stars - service. People seemed irritated often, especially those who you have to collect your food from when they shout your nickname over the loudspeaker (and yes, a nickname is required. They ask guys to come up with a porn star name; girls, just any nickname will do).  

3.5 stars - food. I had the egg sliders. Delish. I also ordered, as an extra, their pickled slaw. Not great. It is not mixed together (the cabbage is separate from the slaw topping), but they serve it in a container way too small to allow me to mix it up myself (this might be a new pet peeve of mine...food served in bowls and plates that are clearly too small). 

So you need to decide what you're looking for. If it's a chill atmosphere with yummy drinks (that you get yourself and take a bit of time), then this is your place.

So yeah!!! This place was recommended to my wife by friends who lucky I still call them friends after my experience.  The setup is cool, it is swanky and hip.  I dig that. 

The food I give 4 thumbs down. I had eggs, only thing I could eat pretty much. My wife had the ribs, which I will suggestion you avoid at all cost. They, the ribs, straight assaulted my senses. And we had to 30 minutes wait when nobody was really there. 

Customer service was okay. Really nice bartender. Very helpful.  The girl who took the order, helpful.  

Parking: it sucks! 

Drinks are good though but pricey. 

Overall: I more than will not return and my stomach hurts from the food.

I went with my friends and family and had a great time. I got the black blue pancake for dinner. It was so delicious. But you are ordering from a permanent food truck. (Stays in one spot). And there is only one kitchen, so if you are going and it is packed then your food may take a while. When I went there was a reserved party for like 125 people who were all like 26. So it was crazy and really loud. There are fun things to do like ping pong, cornhole, boxing, and connect four. There desserts are really delicious and when you order you have to create a funny nickname for when your food is ready. Overall it was a fun place with delicious food, so I recommend coming here.

Dinner before the basketball game. Mac & cheese muffins - must have. Sample slider all good but personally loved the brisket. 3 cheese dip delish. The dice lemonade which is homage and worth it not too sweet or too tart and you don't taste the alcohol. Love the ambiance!!!!

I had an amazing experience planning and hosting my daughter's 17th birthday party with the help of Frankie in Event Sales. She was extremely accommodating and a pleasure to work with. She went beyond the call of duty in answering my questions and helping me make decisions.

The Duce was a perfect location for a party with all ages. The teenagers had a great time playing corn hole and ping pong and the adults had fun cocktails. Everyone loved the decor.

Now on to the food, this is why we wanted to plan the party at The Duce to begin with. We have not had anything at The Duce that was not amazing. The sliders are great and the mac and cheese is delicious!

All around The Duce is always a great place to go.

A funky bar with food is the best description for this little joint; . it's actually a huge Warehouse build in half indoors and half Outdoors with funky drinks made with fresh fruit and delicious pot pie served in a mason jar .We will be back.

Wow, this is a tough one. I first heard of this spot a few weeks ago and have been dying to try it.

Today I decided to take my Mom out for breakfast and we hit The Duce. Getting there early, we had the place to ourselves. As others have mentioned, there is a LOT going on here, it can be a bit tricky to navigate/comprehend what all is going on, but it's very well done.

The Duce is housed in a beautiful old warehouse in downtown, and if you loathe strip malls like I do, you'll find The Duce a welcome change. Concrete floors, old brick, reclaimed wood, it's great.

We were warmly greeted by a friendly woman who explained how things worked and gave us the lay of the land. The staff member told us about the great food and told us to either order at the bar or trailer.  We wandered around, taking it all in and then went to the food service/bar area of the business.

Because we were having drinks with breakfast, we decided to order at the bar. After waiting seven minutes to get someone to come over, an angry looking guy ambled over (picture a chubby Amish guy with terrible prison quality tats)

I say hello to the .bartender and tell him we wanted to order breakfast. He grunts, looks displeased and says that we're supposed to order at the trailer. I inform him that we were told we can order here, and since we want drinks we decided to take care of it all at the bar. Speaking of booze, I ordered two bloody mary's. The bartender made a face that would have made sense if I asked him for a kidney. He looked under the bar and said he would only be able to make ONE bloody mary. Keep in mind we are the FIRST customers on a Sunday morning. I was truly puzzled that they could not have the basic ingredients for a breakfast drink staple, much like how it would be if In-N-Out ran out of hamburger.

I pay for our stuff and he mumbles something that could be Mandarin, or Pig Latin, I was unsure. I asked him to repeat himself and he was able to use his words and tell me to listen for my name to be called  when our food was ready. We found a seat and my Mom was asking what the guy's problem was, and I told her I wondered the same thing. Fellow Yelpers, please know- I am a really laid back guy, I don't get stressed, and can tolerate a lot! That ends when you're treating my Mom poorly, that is NOT okay, especially when we passed over 100 different breakfast spots just to try out The Duce( Matt's Big Breakfast anyone?).

Moving on, sorry this is sooo long, but it was so shocking how shitty the service was, really! The place was really cool, the food was pretty good, and the other employee was SO sweet, but sadly all that was negated by the shat service by the bartender. He truly was a turd. Yikes.

I will be giving this place another shot, and hopefully they find the bartender a personality transplant and/or the right combination of meds so he no longer a prick. If not, they will need to change the name of the place from The Duce, to The Douche.

Quick Review...

Car Park
-valet
-street (not too well lit)

Adult Bevies
-mason  jars 
-2 sizes ... 16 and I believed it was 23 oz
-over priced
-bar tenders we encountered tonite were  not cordial nor friendly at all 
(one seemed to be more focus on texting than assisting us)

No Cover for today! ^_^

Karaoke

Dancing

Toilet was dirty and no Toilet Paper in  both stalls (W).

Food/Food Service
-we loved the sliders
-we hated the brisket sliders ... too ssweet, and the buns were wet and soggy.
-service was slooooow 
-order food from the Trailer/kitchen (?)

Ambience 
-casual
-loungey/chill
-inviting

Overpriced drinks. Terrible service regarding food. I wish I could review the food, but I waited over an hour and didn't get any food. The atmosphere is cool and the concept is alright, just poorly executed.

Everybody calm down. Put your Two Door Cinema Club and Andrew Bird albums away. I see you have the newest Apple product...   alas, they are no auditions happening at this time for Portlandia in this place.

Ok now I have that of the way. Aside from the iconic NW drab and decor, the Duce is the best place you dont want to enjoy. Reason being is, the place cultivates trend, and epitomizes liberality from the AZ Scottsdale gilded cake faces and shiny car Dbags. 

A centralized focus on passive cult trends and proactive enthusiasm for the antipodes.

I see the NW, where the happiest excitement in life is to be convinced that one is fighting for all one is worth on behalf of some clearly seen and deeply felt good, and against some greatly scorned evil.
 
Welcome to AZ.

R\_

NOte, Trying to cover the overhead? PBR? 3 dollars?  Easy breezy...it is just beer. Kinda $$$.

Really cool vibe....old warehouse turned in to this funky bar/playground....the staff were a lot of fun, and I bet the place gets CRAZY on a Friday or Saturday night!! The food is decent as well and everything is priced accordingly....will definitely return!!!

Great bar that brings back the old school vibes of Chicago. Met the owner over the weekend and you can tell why the poace is so beloved. Great drinks and beer selection. A must if you are in the PHX area.

At first I didn't find any appeal in dinning at a place like this. Best way to put it, the duce is more  like a place for single people who drink, eat, and dance. It's good for parties and what not. It's gets really busy and packed at night! They have a complimentary valet. Overall, despite the unusual experience, it wasn't bad. I didn't eat anything, but the drinks are good. Food can be a little pricy. Drinks are average priced. I'll probably be back one day...
Awesome atmosphere with a lot to do. Great bar and drink selection. Great food too! This is a great place to come and hang out.

Ah "The Duce"! I was fortunate enough to attend a company event here with a concert. This rating is not for the event because the company who put it on did a great job! The concept for this place is great, the feel is very cool. It reminds me of several of the old music spots from when I was a kid back east. We did not eat any food so I can not comment on that. Some advice I have to whoever runs this place. To start the night we were crammed outside waiting for the main doors to open. Drinks were sluggish and hard to obtain in general. It took 20 minutes to get our first drink at a walk up bar. Once inside loved the idea, but execution is lacking. Again, drink service was lacking. Add bartenders! Bottle fresh squeezed juice instead of squeezing each drink! Now....the drinks were outstanding! A little light on the pours, but the taste made up for it. The layout inside is confusing. I liked it but success is in the details. It seems like the owners or operators have a great idea but they may not have any restaurant/ bar/ music experience. Last, as the band was playing we could hear the food orders over the PA system...... Uh I don't care who's order is up. It is rude to the band and hard to stay focused to the music for the listener. I will go back which is why I gave this place 3 stars. Not sure how long they have been open, maybe it's just issues with a new place.

This is a really unique place. If you just want to hang out and have drinks in January, this may be a great option. However.....My co-workers and I tried to have lunch at Duce during the week because we had heard the sliders were scrumptious. We ordered lunch at 11:30AM and left with no food at 12:30PM. The kitchen is just too small and disorganized to produce meaningful amounts food during lunch hour. There was also no evidence of any management on site. Waiting for an hour without A/C for no food was a real downer and has soured our opinion of this joint. Triple D got hoodwinked on this one.

We had my daughters graduation party here. I must admit after emailing back and forth with the party planner I was worried. She seemed a little negative and we were getting opposite answers from her than what we had been told when we visited in person. We couldn't afford the packages they offered and I was hesitant after that not so positive emails, but decided to go with our original plan- we ordered giant pitchers of tea and lemonade, as well as, several appetizers. The girl at the trailer was super helpful and accommodating. We were originally told we'd need to arrive early to save spots since we were doing the party on our own. We got their an hour ahead of time and while my dad was checking out the place he stumbled across some saved seats with my name on it- pleasant surprise!! All in all it turned out great! We got several compliments from our friends and family that showed up, some even stayed after the party had ended to continue having fun with all of the games! I would have given 5 starts, if not for the party planner, as she was not very helpful, and was the main reason for any stress surrounding the party! Also- would be nice to be able to bring in our own cake!

It's located in a sort of run down area. I was unimpressed with the amount of food and quality that you get for the price. It was really loud and I ended up tipping (push the smaller no tip button on the bottom of the screen to not tip) assuming they bring the food to you, but you stand there for your silly made up name to be called. This place pales in comparison to the 5 other places you pass to even find it. I was thoroughly unimpressed, but I guess it's a great place for hipsters to hang out.
The Duce has great food and a fun atmosphere. I love the swing lessons on Tuesday nights, the macaroni and cheese muffins are to die for and their mixed drinks are always amazing!

Not too crowded after a day game at Chase Field. This place is located just outside the "ballpark" zone, so probably doesn't draw that kind of crowd. The additional parking sign could have been better as we ended up having to pay for a few hours at the meter instead of finding the overflow parking. Inside, the place does have all the fun stuff and we played pong, foosball, cornhole and checked out the shop and boxing ring too. We had no line ordering and food was out quickly. 
   Mac N Cheese Muffins - what else can you say..these are top notch and filling.
Brisket Sliders - great brisket, no fat and soft rolls with a tasty unknown BBQ sauce
Shepherd's Pie in a jar - another winner. The potatoes were so creamy (and colorful) and each bite was pretty wonderful with the slightly greasy meat and other ingredients just coming together in a good fashion.
   There was no AC (swamp coolers) in this giant warehouse (rough in July) and the famous pot pie uses mixed dark and white meat, but otherwise this was a pretty fun experience and great food. Oh yeah, happy hour has $2 beers, but Hamm's was a bad choice.
Had a great lunch! The mac & cheese muffins were awesome. We also had a basket of various sliders, yummy!!

The Duce was our 2nd stop of my family's quest to try as many of the Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives restaurants located in the Phoenix/Scottsdale area.  If you want to take the entire family to an adult and kid friendly restaurant, you won't be disappointed by this fun and foodie friendly destination.  

Don't be deceived by the old looking, warehouse-like appearance of The Duce.  You'll be pleasantly surprised by all the quirky things found inside.  Prominently displayed as you enter the restaurant are the spray painted picture of Guy Fieri and his framed picture next to a Coca-Cola bottle fridge indicating that The Duce was featured on Triple D.  I took my son, niece, nephew, and in-laws and their eyes widened with joy as they saw all The Duce offered.  There was a full size boxing ring, boxing heavy bag and punching bag, ping pong tables, fooseball table, bean bag toss games similar to horseshoes, apparel store with quirky tshirts, hats, and shoes, bicycles, soda shop, and old school bleachers.  You have to check out the restrooms, which have corrugated fencing for toilet stall dividers.  Right where Guy's spray painted face is, there's a DJ platform playing classic, old school music.  My family loved this place so much that they would have been content taking selfies and photographs of all the cool, picture friendly sights.  I really loved this place because of the ping pong table and the really fun games.  My son and nephew would have rathered play all of the games then eat.  I'll take both the food and games.

Fun, interactive games and delicious food. Sign me up.  The Duce did not disappoint and once again, Guy Fieri knows great food.  Don't let your eyes order the food because if you do, you'll order more than you could eat.  My son and I ordered the family sliders comprised of your choice of 7  delicious sliders.  Honestly, this family meal is more than enough to feed a family of 4.  I picked the cheeseburger, egg, brisket, barbeque rib, and chicken sausage.  I loved the egg, chicken sausage, and cheeseburger.  My family loved the brisket.  The egg was dripping with finger licking yolk and combined with thick, savory bacon, I wanted another one.  The sausage  was thick and juicy.  I know, I know, that's what she said.  Cheeseburger was tasty and had yummy, melted cheese.  The bread used for the sliders were inconsistent, some hard and some soft.  Wish all of them were soft.  The one thing that is a must order are the cornbread, mac and cheese muffins.  These moist, cheesy and fluffy delights were morsels of foodie goodness.  OMG multiple times.  One thing I forgot to mention are the shakes.  My niece had the s'mores shake and my one slurp made me regret not ordering it.  Wow, it was sweet, smooth and I loved my tease of this delicious drink.

If you're looking for a fun, interactive restaurant that serves delicious, tasty and filling food, drop into The Duce.  After the tummy busting food, you might have to drop a Duce.  Their restrooms are clean and fun to hang out in, so you'll be alright.

I have heard about the Duce for a long time so I came in on a Saturday during the day. Other reviews have mentioned how cool the place is. Totally true! Very little parking. 

Highlights: the drinks. The bartender made the drinks in mason jars and would put on a top and shake it in the jar and serve it to you. The Bloody Mary used locally produced Bloody Mary mix, fresh squeezed lemon and lime juice, muddled olives, celery salt, and a pickle. 

The Mac and cheese muffins are sinful and delicious with panko bread crumbs. 

During the day it's pretty empty and laid back.

Duce's Wild! Me and 4 girlfriends came here Saturday for drinks and food and had a blast!
All the drinks were made with fresh ingredients, my favorite has to be the Cherry Sidecar made with strawberries. You can't taste the alcohol but I was feeling great once we left 
The d√©cor is very vintage and unique. I highly recommend this place especially for a big group.

I LOVE this spot! It is one of my go to places now! The drinks are great and the atmosphere is even better. They have multiple bars inside, dance floor, games, little place to shop, great music! I will definitely be back here very soon!

Ok, this place is for the younger crowd, but we found ourselves visiting for a company party. It is a great place to meet up with friends and play games. There are several ping-pong tables, toss games, checkers, and foosball! 

I guess cocktails are good as well. The beer selection is generic macrobrew, which means typical American beers. 

The best thing was the valet parking! They are on top of it. www.EpicValet.com Waiting for our car which did not take long at all I had time to talk with employees and found out they offer valet service to Phoenix Sky Harbor! New service. Drop off car at the airport and they pick it up and park it in their secure location. You can have it washed or what ever while in their care. Car is dropped off when you arrive at the airport ready to go! Can't wait to check it out!

I'm undecided about this place.  I heard about their drinks made from fresh fruit and was interested to try.  What I did not expect was that it was going to be an old school gym/boxing ring/ping ponging place serving food out of an airstream.  

I can't lie, the drinks WERE good.  They seem a bit spendy but given the size, it feels like a decent deal.  However, we later concluded that they aren't terribly strong and they use ice to make it seem like you're getting much more than you actually are.  

The food was surprisingly good.  The mac n' cheese muffins were pretty tasty and the s'mores cheesecake (which, be forewarned, is an actual small cheesecake) was quite delicious (although maybe a skosh too much marshmallow).
Place is kind of cool. Restaurant, bar, boxing and they sale clothes. Also have a place to play 4 square. drinks are awesome. haven't tried food yet.  No air conditioning so dress the part.
Really recommend Tuesday Swing Dancing. A lot of fun -- cool people throughout All levels of dancers -- it was my first time. Good date night :)

This place is so friggin' cool, I am surprised that more people do not know about it!  Um, I think you HAVE to love beer (specifically Wisconsin beer) memorabilia, you have to love Anthropologie like clothing, you have to love good old fashioned drinks, like Greyhounds, Old Fashioneds, and Sidecars.  You have to love home made potato chips and a wait staff who want to call you by a nickname.  You have to love cool, old warehouses and funky people, and the unexpected.  I'm in love.

How do I explain the Duce? Sometimes I think Phoenix is what Brooklyn could be if it had more space. 
The Duce seems like an experiment- it's a bar/dessert truck/boxing ring (?)/dance floor/general store/wedding reception space and probably other things I'm leaving out. Here's what you need to try: apple cider beer- it's locally made and crazy-delicious. The bartender told me all girls love it! My boyfriend and I were silly enough to split a smore's pie we saw off the menu of the cute little aluminum dessert truck. We thought it would come in a mason jar situation, but it was the size of nearly a regular pie!! My fork had greater staying power than his, but even I had had enough of marshmallowy goodness. I'm not sure if we'll be back but it's definitely worth a visit. I'm still dreaming about that pie.

Great place! Dropping my son off to college and thought we would try it out. Came in on Saturday afternoon and it was the perfect time. Not packed at all. Order you food and play the games while it is cooked to order. Everything was cooked perfectly and the taste was ridiculously good. Walked out happy and full!

The place isn't hard to find, just keep an eye out on the left when you're heading south on Central. Get to Lincoln and take a left.
 My first impression, parking is waaay tiny and seemed to be first come first set-the-rule-for-everybody-else.
 I guess after 5 it's valet, so add a second tip into what you expect to spend when comin' out. I'm not cheap but I dislike the valet in your face idea that seems to be creeping up to casual places. But hey, that's me.

 Your first experience is the retail area. Some of the clothes look fun but it's pretty much greys, khaki's, and greens in various rugged incarnations. Kinda wish I'd have gotten some of those boots though. 

 The produce area was an afterthought. I'm at a place that has a a portion of the word 'Produce' as it's name and the only thing that I considered taking home was a lemon...to clean my garbage disposal. I had been hoping for some jalapenos or cabbage or pickled something. The salsa in the mason jar was tempting, I'll probably get some next time. And those boots.

 A  nice fella came over to chat me up when he saw I was poking about. He explained to me some of the highlights of the place, the old school bus they'll use to ferry people to first friday and home games, the stadium benches they have in front of a decent size projection screen for watching games (and a larger flatscreen in the booze area!), etc. etc. He was warm and genuine and told me that they really want to be a place for locals. Come down, bring a book, get a soda or a beer, take a nap, hit the heavy bag for a bit and grab some grub before going home. Like a YMCA for the hip and spendy. 
 When I was there two guys were doing a pretty legit workout. Pullups, speed bag, timing each other, etc. There is something ultra satisfying to be sitting at a bar, drinking a beer, with the *real* sound of a slappity-thump-thump badass on the speedbag.

 I could see doing that. I got a vibe of  potential hang out, regular friendly, new social experience. 

 The staff was great at handling somebody who was trying to figure out what was what with a place that is wearing so many hats at once.  
 The bar has a great selection of drinks made easy. If all else fails you can pickup a chalkboard menu at several spots and just point at what you want. The beers are on ice right in front of you so when you take that first drink you're reminded that not all beer should be Sono-err-Sun Up Brewing style and served a fistful of degrees above room. If it's triple digits outside and you're in a big brick building an ice cold beer can kick ass. 
 I gotta say though, a can of Old Milwaukee, for $4? Really? I can get a six pack of Simpler Times at Trader Joe's for less than that.
 I didn't get to try the food, I was still stuffed from lunch, but the smells coming off the grill were great.

 If this place gets some decent happy hour specials I'll be there pretty often.
We did not have a good time, we waited 15 minutes at the bar and the bartenders ignored us and went straight the the caucasian customers. Eventually we got fed up and left.
Worst place ever wouldn't let us inside because of some event...was not told before hand. Patio smelled terrible...sewer issue never come here!

What the hell is this place? Hipster heaven, bring the kids and babies to drink night?  I can't even imagine work get togethers here with all the kids running around. Had a beer until my party arrived so we can leave together and thought about food. Line was long for no reason and on top of that, the food wait was one hour! What is going on here and who had the idea for this place? I just don't get it.

I love this place in every way. I tried to read recent reviews to see if there was a temperature issue since I have never been there in the summer and I know they only have swamp coolers. Well tonight it was quite warm and only fans were used. I saw they got new swamp coolers but they didn't seem to be in use. Bummer. I agree that their drinks are expensive ($5 for strawberry lemonade that was mainly ice.)  but the ambiance is awesome and fun. We had to ask the DJ to turn down the music so we could talk.

Used to be my favorite place but tonight was just lame. The DJ sucked & the live music was awful...no dance music, nothing. I used to be totally willing to pay a ton of money for drinks here but now that the vibe has changed I probably won't be back. We came with a large party & we were all just praying for the band to be done and some fun music to dance to. Such a bummer.
Yet again triple D doesn't disappoint. This place is great the atmosphere is contagious and the food was great. I will be back and I'm bringing friends

Super fun environment! I had a great time. There's a lot of activities, great food, and good fresh drinks! I would recommend this place for the weekend. Great place to have a great time with good company!

Interesting place, many activities for families to do. It took two hours to get our food order due to some in-house computer glitch. Kids were starving and we received two free orders of Mac n cheese muffin shareables, which were out of this world delicious. The adult lemonade and vodka was tasty too. Our sandwiches were okay, not great. I would return for those fabulous m&c muffins!!

This is a magical place.

I was here on a Thursday night when it wasn't very crowded and I assume it can get crazy. This is a massive space, like an old boxing gym (there is a ring and punching bags). You can have drinks, play cornhole, sing karaoke, buy vintage clothes, whatevs.

This is the grown up version of the place you design as a kid. I really enjoyed it.

This place was so much fun. The DJ on Saturday was brilliant. The food is a bit expensive but the mac and cheese muffins were incredible. There is an amazing open roof section, a cool dance floor, a bunch of games, and a boxing ring right in the center. The atmosphere is more casual and almost like an upscale dive bar. If you want to let loose in a t shirt and some jeans, this is the place. A little low on bartending staff but those try keep know what they're doing.

We sauntered down here after a ballgame to grab a drink on a Saturday night. Like other have said, it is in a dark part of town, so make sure you have a buddy or two if you are parking there. The place screams hipster, but is tolerable for a few hours, especially since there is so much going on to distract yourself. The snack food was decent and the drinks were original and decent. Since the place is essentially a giant warehouse it is great for larger groups, however, as others mention it might be uncomfortable staying there for a few hours given the AC situation. One thing that really confuse me was having a boutique-like store in the middle of place that is essentially a bar and adult playground. If I was ever interested in buying a $180 sweatshirt, I doubt it would be from the same place I order a GnT from. I probably wouldn't make a special trip, however, will keep it in mind if I am ever looking for something different downtown.

I was at a running event and I happened to see a warehouse surrounded by chain link fences and with christmas lights on the doorway. I walked in to quench my thirst for adventure and expected to get stabbed, but I was greeted to what appeared to be a mix between a 50's style fountain shop, people dancing to swing, and a scene from Million Dollar Baby. 

I ordered the short rib sliders expecting some cardboard white castle knockoff, but what touched my taste buds was pure meaty tenderness melting away like butter with a kiss of apple leaving me wanting for more. 

The service seemed great to me. The girl near the trailer area, she rocks and was about as high spirited as you can get without drugs.

In short, this place has a lot of soul. It reminds me of some places I use to go to in Austin. I'm glad places like this exist in Phoenix and hopefully stay around so that my options aren't limited to yet another sports bar with patrons staring slack jawed at the plasma screen ahead periodically grunting loudly when something happens.
Fun and very inventive dishes that taste amazing.  Tad pricy and drink refills aren't included, but the food makes up for it.

Not sure if you'd call this place a restaurant, an amusement park, a vintage clothing store, or a soundstage for a '30's Chicago boxing movie.  I just know I love any excuse to go there and have fun! Steve and Andi have created a one of a kind place with something for everyone.  If you're looking for some place memorable to take visiting guests, think this place.  I think this year's Christmas wish list is going to be "anything vintage from the store at The Duce."

First time I went it was a weekday happy hour in January. I absolutely loved it with their unique ambiance and their food truck kitchen and their creative yummy drinks. But my recent visit in a hot and humid summer afternoon changed that completely. It's a warehouse turned into restaurant, so there's no a/c in there. In Duce's defense, weather was bad. But that wasn't the only problem. I was at the bar for a good 10 mins. I didn't even get a "I'll get you in a minute" from the bar tender. I decided to be a teetotaler (for the day, of course!) and moved to the food counter. The line was bog which is ok. I ordered a scramble. ETA - one and half hours!! It actually took more like 2 hours. THAT IS OUTRAGEOUS!! I had ordered avocados in my scramble. I got none of it, nor an apology or even a mere mention. Bottom line - the restaurant looks cool and unique. But all that becomes irrelevant when it fails in the primary objective of an eatery which is to provide food and drinks to its patrons. This is also in a not-so-great neighborhood. So if they don't get their act together soon, people will just stop going.

We enjoyed awesome cocktails and some kick butt sliders! Our favorite was the brisket sliders! Then, for desert we had the cinnamon cheese cake. It was a little too much for 2 people but we brought the rest home and will be having it as a midnight snack! Yum!

Really a cool set up....mostly outdoors or at least open to the outdoors, boxing ring, good bar, picnic tables (you can bring the pooch!), small retail area, etc.  The mac & cheese balls were so good, the sliders were good, the drinks a little on the pricey side but they had some unique ones to choose from.  Overall, a fun place to visit!
Great atmosphere. Love cocktails and music. Food is yummy but takes a long time. I left my wallet and they put it behind the bar and nothing was missing when I went to fetch it.

I went there a couple weeks ago with my girlfriend and we decided to order the french toast and a side of scrambed eggs with spinach and chicken sausage. The food was pretty good especially the french toast, but the service didn't match. Well I guess the service did match...the name that is. If the food wasn't as good as it was  I would've given this place 2 stars. My girlfriend wanted to order coffee and they told her that they were all out. There was only one pot sitting at the counter and it was empty. One pot??? For a place this big they only make one pot of coffee??? A couple of minutes after we ordered our food a two people walked up and ordered theirs. Our food came out somewhat fast, but theirs did not. They didnt get their food until at least 15 min after we ate ours. A couple of others walked up to order coffee and the host/server said they were out. The guy asked if they could make more but all the server could say was "we've been getting orders for coffee all day and we keep running out.". The guy asks if they could make more and the server just throws his arms up. The man looked pretty upset and just walked away. He couldve just took a couple mins to brew a fresh batch but didn't. This place needs to get better training for their servers.

This is one of the best hangouts in all of Phoenix! Great for anyone and kids. As a parent, you can hang out get good eats and your kids will have some entertainment. They have bean bag toss, ping pong, space to run, a store to explore and the best part. An amazing selection of craft drinks and adult beverages ;). The food is served in adorable mason jars and is hearty and delicious! They have a good cover of gluten free items for folks like me. This will always be my anytime hangout in Phoenix!

I love it.  An amazing multi-use building full of all kinds of cool things.  The food was fantastic, the music was fun, the fresh squeezed lemonade was tasty and the atmosphere was super cool.  No poseurs here.

So unexpected, so fun, so yummy!

The venue is a huge space.  Retro w/o being trying too hard.  Loved having a DJ spinning motown.  I'm struggling to think of a place in town with drinks as terrific as these.  All are made from scratch as each drink is made.  Fruit cut, oranges squeezed on a per drink basis.  And the sliders are a treat, especially the brisket.  

We were there on a slower night and still had a blast.  I'd love to see what it is like when it is really hopping.  Can't think of a better place to take a big crew.

Looking for a fun place to throw your birthday party or even just wind down on a Friday night? I LOVE the retro-chic atmosphere of The Duce for any occasion! It's fully equipped with a delicious food truck {best sliders ever}, fabulous mason jar drinks, activities, art and really anything that your heart desires. You and your guests are sure to have a fun time!

Hosted 30 people. A good time was had by all. Music was fun and danceable. Enough space and things to do that folks with children were comfortable. Food was good. Everyone raved about the Mac and cheese balls. Skip the Chile though. Dips good, deserts good. Sliders okay. 
Good thing they have fans cause it was warm in thete. Good hoop dancing was great. All in all a fun venue and I would recommend. Kudos to Keeley.

What a hidden friggen gem! From the outside you have NO idea what to expect but I was very pleasantly surprised. Around each corner is something new and exciting from the kareoke to the dance floor, to the boxing ring, to the food truck, and the store. Tons of fun!!! I can't wait to go back. My only complaint but also a compliment is that the drinks are pricey. Most likely because they're made with all organic fruits or veggies, etc. They're delicious - don't get me wrong! I tried their lemonade with vodka and also their bloody mary - YUMMMM! But they're pricey ($12+) and they take FOREVER to make. I sat at the bar for probably 20 min before I was even acknowledged. The bartender wasn't being rude, just really busy. I would have drank a lot more if it didn't take so long to get served. 4 stars for the ambiance & the cool vibe. 2 stars for the service.

This place is really unique, lots of games, lots of sitting areas, great dj, two bars a place for food even up until 11 (maybe open even later than that not sure) overall, I really like the layout. The reason why I had to take 3 stars away was because it was dangerously hot (112 degrees no airflow no breeze indoors) and there was only one large fan for that huge enclosed game room area and dancing area. I don't see how the workers were okay with such poor conditions. Everyone was sweating and my friend so dizzy and so sick that she threw up because of the heat. It's unacceptable to work in that kind of condition! Workers were running around doing their job with sweat dripping down their face! There were people walking around with under boob sweat (men and women). Even the bartender was so busy quickly wiping his sweat several times before it could possibly fall in your drink!! I'm telling you the heat and lack of ac or air flow in a huge venue holding about 100 people absolutely CAN'T be unjustified. If Arizona doesn't have any strict building codes for providing proper air flow or air conditions for communal places, then I feel sorry for the workers!!! I hope this post can help spread awareness to the owners on how uncomfortable my experience was and provide a better working condition for those hard workers there. Couldn't even drink (no business) because I was so focused on hydrating and keeping my blood pressure low from the anxiety. Horrible place for the summer time. And I feel bad because like I said in the beginning, lots of great perks for a fun night out in downtown. Just no ac!

Loved this place from the second we walked in! So much going on. The drinks were delicious and the whole chicken was amazing. We also got a couple sides, both of which were also fantastic. There is an area where they teach swing classes, which was a lot of fun to watch while we ate. I would love to come here regularly. I would like to try other drinks and menu items, as well as try a swing class.
Cool place but don't try to arrange a special event. The proprietor was arragont, unflexible and unethical when I held my friend's bachelorette party at The Duce. Be warned!

The Duce is without question one of the coolest adaptive reuse spaces I've ever seen.  Located just south of the Downtown Phoenix high rises on the northeast corner of Central & Lincoln, The Duce has breathed new life into a warehouse building that likely would've otherwise stared down the barrel of a wrecking ball.  Built in 1928, the old Anchor Manufacturing building was bought in 2007 by Chicago transplants Steve & Andi Rosenstein who then poured years of rehab work into the structure while adding tons of nostalgic touches.  There are so many personalities in this one spot that it really does need to be seen to be believed.  I've known about The Duce for years, but wasn't sure what to make of it prior to coming here.  Reviews I'd read about the food in particular were mixed, so I wasn't sure what I'd be getting into.  Finally, I made my way here for an early Tuesday dinner.

Parking at The Duce, as others have accurately noted, is a challenge.  The main parking lot is super tiny with room for no more than a dozen cars (& even then its a tight squeeze).  There's supposedly an overflow lot on Central & Grant (about two blocks south), but I didn't confirm that.  I did notice they started complementary valet parking at 5pm so if you're coming anytime after 5 it appears they've got you covered.  Enter through the building's east side onto the main outdoor patio where you're greeted by a bar on the right & an airstream trailer on your left.  Order your food at the counter in front of the trailer & then proceed to wander.  Once inside the warehouse, there's so much to explore you'll forget how long it took to get your food.  Among the things to see & do inside: Another bar, a dessert bar, corn hole toss, ping pong, hula hoops, vintage clothing & accessories, a boxing ring, foosball, shuffleboard, & tons of seating (including bleacher seats).  For those of you who've been to Sam Fox's The Yard, think of The Duce as The Yard on steroids (& at least 3 times bigger).  This venue has big events written all over it.  If I were having a big reception or get together, The Duce would be an ideal space with lots of food & drinks to choose from & tons of activities.  

The menu at The Duce is all over the map, but I had seen from Guy Fieri's visit here how so much of what they make here is put in jars.  So okay, let's have something out of a jar.  How about their Buttermilk Mashed In A Jar?  And yes that would be mashed potatoes with copious amounts of butter, & I got them loaded with creme fraiche, bacon & cheese.  I also decided to go with their Slider Sampler plate.  A meatball slider, a brisket slider, & a chicken sausage slider to be exact.  While I waited for my dinner I walked over to their dessert bar & ordered one of their pies in a jar.  In this case, an Apple Caramel pie in a jar with whipped cream seemed appropriate.  Total cost for all the food including tax came to $24.

First, the Buttermilk Mashed.  Superb dish served piping hot from the trailer with nice chunks of bacon & lots of cheese.  I wasn't kidding when I said there was a lot of butter in these, but I'm not complaining.  Great starter.  Next up, the sliders.  The chicken sausage is simmered in PBR (just the way I used to do sausages in college, actually) & topped with peppers & onions.  Not bad, though from my experience a brat is the way to go when cooking in PBR.  The meatball slider is a mix of veal, pork, & beef & coated in tomato sauce & what I believe was shaved parmigiano reggiano cheese.  No qualms about this one.  Super juicy & the meatball was plenty large.  Lastly, the brisket slider.  The gal at the front hyped this one up quite a bit for me.  Though if you've been to Little Miss BBQ as many times as I have, that's a pretty tough standard to top.  The Duce's brisket is quite good & the slider portion was hearty, but c'mon we both know nothing beats Little Miss brisket.  All in all an okay slider trio.  Lastly, the Apple Caramel Pie.  I have to take some of the blame on this because I should've insisted on having this heated up.  Because getting through the crust of the pie was brutally tough.  The crust was thick & pretty rock hard.  If I had nuked it for a minute, this pie would've been perfect.  That said, once I did penetrate the crust there was plenty of delicious caramel mixed in with those apple slices.  So lesson learned:  If you get the pie, ask them to heat it up just a bit.

In terms of a venue, The Duce is 5 stars all the way.  Super eclectic, super unique, super fun spot that would appeal to pretty much any age group.  Heck I'm thinking I should take one of their swing dance classes on Tuesdays.  As far as the food, I'll give it 3 stars as it was a little hit or miss.  The menu is as creative as the space itself, though with somewhat more mixed results.  As a whole, a venue that everyone should come see at least once.  Its a marvel of creativity, innovation, & nostalgia.  And big enough to invite your whole neighborhood over

Giving one star took effort! Moving forward I will ALWAYS read reviews. AMAZING drinks, hands down! A little pricey but fresh organic ingredients make it worth the price! Swanky spot with a dope atmosphere. Good music too! Very slow service, below average food and small portions. My hubby & I are gluten free and most of the menu contains sliders. I ordered the ribs and my husband had an egg skillet. I took one bite and left my food on the table. I may go back but it will only be after dinner and for drinks only! And...I plan to email the restaurant about my concerns.

This place is something else... Hidden just south of Downtown Phoenix right behind US Airways Arena. You'll miss it if you're not looking for it and you'll be glad if you drop in. Hard to explain the concept but it's an old historic warehouse --turned gym/bar/diner. You walk in and you'll see an old Airstream parked inside, cooking some great sliders and desserts! Walk into the next section and you'll enter the bar area...very vintage look to it, with karaoke the majority of the times I've been there. They offer organic liquor and it's actually not bad. If you order mixed drinks or anything of that nature, they use fresh fruits and will make everything fresh! Look into the next room and you'll see the boxing ring, then a little further you'll see vintage clothing for sale! This place is definitely somewhere to take guests from out-of-town or a place to grab a great drink with friends. Just go there!

Great concept!  Something Phoenix sorely needs.  A creative approach to retail.  Kind of a Fred Segal wanna be on a small scale.

Now the bad news.  If they don't get the retail side of this concept going right off the bat they will blow it.  A space this big needs some serious energy!!!  Get rid of the gym area as no one will use it for its intended purpose.  Pump up the retail!!!!  I get that you want to sell your own brand but when that brand is mainly thermals and army pants it is not gonna happen.  Don't put all of your eggs in this retail basket.  This is AZ bring in some great t-shirt lines, flip flops, athletic gear!!  And the #1 seller in AZ JEWELRY!!!! Lines to consider; splendid, C&C, Seneca Rising, James Perse, Rene Garvey jewelry, Lost Bird jewelry (a local)))
that kind of vibe will do wonders for this place as these designers have a huge following even in Phoenix!

This space is crying out for cool trunk shows on the weekends by great local designers!  I'm not talking Grandmas knitting I mean cool stuff.   Think Renegade crafts people!! This is also a great way to build up the customer base as you put some of the work onto the crafts people.  Choose locals who have a following!  Not only do you get a % of what they sell but you get their customers!!

And the music!!!  C'mon!!!  Have to find good bands.  No more Joe Shmoe and his keyboard.

I'm hoping this place figures it out cause it could be really cool.

I first entered The duce on October 15th, 2009 when Mayor Phil Gordon hosted a tour of renovated downtown buildings.  Steve and Andi Rosenstein have taken a vintage 1928 produce warehouse and turned it into a mixed use building containing a bar/restaurant, retail space, coffee bar, florist shop and gym. This is a very cool project that will be a staple of the "new downtown" scene in Phoenix. Check it out!

Revised Post Opening:

Opening weekend went well although by all admissions another two weeks of setup was needed.

Maybe I'm just too old for this place but as a 30 year old, I felt like an outsider.  Everyone there seemed to be between 18-22, which to me, seems strange at a bar in downtown Phoenix.  I would have expected feeling that way on Mill Ave! Not that I go to Mill Ave ;) but seriously.  I was with a group of people ranging from 26 to 35 and we all felt extremely old and out of place.  It's a young, hipster place where there's only one beer on draft (it was some vanilla Hefeweizen.... I never heard of Hefeweizen with vanilla and I think there's a very good reason) and nothing good in bottles either (budweiser, miller high life, PBR, schlitz, etc).  How couldn't I find even a Bud Lite or Miller Light?!?!? We stayed for about 10 minutes before calling it a night.

I loved this place.  I can't wait to come back and bring some girlfriends.  This place is so different, I told my husband this is what I imagine a bar in Alabama might look like, kind of Hillbilly cool without the banjos.   LOVED, LOVED, LOVED it.  The drinks are amazing.  I had a couple of the mojitos and they were delicious.  The drinks are made with fresh squeezed juices and you can taste it. My hubby had the Duce Margarita and he said it was fantastic.  We ate a selection of the sliders.  My favorites in order were the egg, brisket, cheese, meatball, chicken sausage.  I also had the sweet potato crisps.  Yummy sweet potato chips, Andy the owner told me they baked them not fried, bonus.  Music is loud, and the ambiance is so much fun.  Andy is so nice and friendly, can't wait to share this experience again.

Oh how I love this place. Let me count the ways:

THE PLACE: Its beautifully industrial, vintage-trailer-park-chic, best-friend's-backyard sort of place. There is no roof, no windows and no overhead lighting. The white Christmas lights surround the walls all-year round and the rows of pinic tables are decorated with fresh flowers regardless how many times people grab them as hair decorations. The food truck is located inside the metal-sheet walls and the makeshift yet beautiful bathrooms remind you that a lot of care was put into this place. On the other side of the bar a whole warehouse of vintage furniture, farmer's market items and games (like hula hooping and darts) make it the larges adult playground ever.

THE DRINKS: Mason jar placed and perfectly executed, they have a full built-in bar with an extensive original cocktail list and a patio bar with a smaller one. The cranberry cobbler is sweet, tart and not overly girly. The mojito is tart yet well executed and the drinks are very approachable at a $8-10 for liquor $3 for beer. Every single cocktail is made with fresh fruit, as you see the bartender grab an orange/grapefruit/lemon from the baskets and cut/juice them for each glass, adding agave nectar for extra sweetness. Its as fresh as it gets and incredibly surprising at a night time bar.

THE PEOPLE: Pretty awesome, both for the working folk as well as the attendees. The bartender in the patio area was very nice and funny and managed to keep a smile despite my friend's glass-breaking, drink-spilling, loud-acting debauchery. She deserves a gold medal for that crap. The strangers were friendly and everyone seemed very open to meeting each other.

THE KARAOKE: Damn that DJ has a voice. A very sultry sultry, should've-joined-a-90s-boy-band voice. All the basics were covered, from Celine Dion to Mariah Carey to Tina Turner. Everyone did an excellent job at background singers/dancers and many rocked our socks off with their crazy good voices. The song book was extremely extensive and the DJ did a great job at keeping the mood positive and fun.

THE OVERALL: The vibe is chill, its drunken, its party mode, its hang-out mode. Its everything you want and more. There isn't a bouncer to stare you down and threaten to kick you out if you don't behave, nor a server that clearly hates her life but is still there serving you a PBR, nor the slutty cocktail-dress dramaholic looking for her pop-collar jersey shore prince. The people want to be there and the image of people riding vintage bicycles around the warehouse is unique, kinda like this place. 

No hipsters, no douchebags no yuppies. Just people. Its good to see that once in a while, ya know?
Great place. So much to do. Great food and drinks. Friendly staff. Food took awhile and they ran out of some items.

I'm not sure why this place has only 3.5 stars. It's amazing! All in one. Ambiance. Music. Delicious food. Customer service was great. Ping pong, corn hole, foosball. Super rustic and funky looking inside. Seriously?? It's amazing!
Nate is the best! I highly suggest you order whatever be suggests! Stumptown Smash or basil gimlet...everything is awesome

I will NEVER be back. Was here for my sisters birthday, I brought her a cake for a gift, wasn't going to eat it there and it was a fully packaged store bought cake. The management would not allow it in the restaurant, not even for a few minutes so she could see it when she arrived. The manager was rude and unreasonable. Then, we ordered drinks and headed over to the corn hole area and we were told no alcohol is allowed in the game area. There is no air conditioner, in Phoenix, and had to sit outside. The drinks are crazy expensive, I don't know why anyone would go here.
